course_title: Introduction to Professional Skills in Occupational Therapy

learning_outcomes.description: Coursework - Identify personal values, beliefs, life experiences and interpersonal characteristics that impact on your development as a health professional (including communication in various contexts), showing self-awareness.
Coursework - Demonstrate the ability to engage in insightful self- reflection regarding professional development (e.g., of personal communication skills).
Coursework - Apply your understanding of interviewing and communication skills to generate, deliver and reflectively respond to peer feedback.
Coursework - Demonstrate verbal and non-verbal therapeutic communication skills including listening, questioning, and assertiveness in 1:1 and group situations.
Coursework - Identify responsive strategies to meet the diverse needs and preferences of all communication partners.
Coursework - Explain the therapeutic (intentional) use of self and the application of these principles to OT practice.

assessments.task_description:
This in-semester exam is scheduled on Monday in Week 7, earlier than (and in lieu of) the usual Monday lecture (the exam has a 15:00 start time). Content from lectures, tutorials and required readings from Weeks 1-6 inclusive is examinable. It is not an open-book exam.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Deferred exams can be requested for this assessment item. Please apply for a deferred exam if there are exceptional or unavoidable circumstances, or as a one-off discretionary request. Deferred exam requests should be submitted as soon as possible, and no later than five calendar days after the date of the original exam. Further details, including how to apply, can be found at - Deferring an exam. Please also email the Course Coordinator to advise of the deferred exam request.

assessments.task_description:
Students will be split into four (4) tutorial groups. You will be assigned to one (1) weekly tutorial group on either Tuesday, Wednesday or Friday.

11 tutorials during the semester (weeks 1-10, and 12) focus on development of core professional skills. To facilitate development of reflective practice, three questions are to be completed in the final 10 minutes of these tutorials. These reflections will be submitted at the end of the tutorial. Each reflection will be worth 1.5 marks and the best 8 will contribute to the total mark (out of 12).

During the tutorial in week 11, students will participate in a practice for their Practical Exam (Final Interview). There will be no ‘tutorial reflection’ submitted during this tutorial, however students will provide a peer with a copy of a completed Peer Interview Feedback Form, which is critical to completion of the Reflection Report assessment, and should be submitted with the Reflection Report assignment.

The tutorial in week 13 is dedicated to supporting preparation for the final two pieces of assessment, and no tutorial reflection will be submitted.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment is to be completed in person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Peer Interview Feedback Form that you completed on your partner during the practice interview in week 11 must be submitted via Turnitin on Learn.UQ when you submit your Reflection Report Assessment.

assessments.task_description:
Reflective practice is the process of reflecting on an experience or activity and underpins occupational therapy practice. You are required to apply a framework for reflection, identifying the strengths and weaknesses in your communication skills, and discerning what you need to focus on to enhance communication in your end-of-semester assessment interview and with your clients in the future.

Refer to the task description and marking rubric that will be in the Assessment Folder on Learn.UQ for further details.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The reflection report is to be submitted online via Turnitin on Learn.UQ.

Online independent learning activities

Students will be informed of online resources relevant to each lecture/tutorial, and are expected to engage independently with the required readings.

Recommended readings are also nominated. These:

  • are provided to support students who wish to review a topic covered in class or extend their understanding of a topic.
  • will not be directly assessed in the in-semester exam.


Online training modules have been designed to complement other learning activites and provide additional opportunities for practicing core communication skills in some weeks of the semester. These are not compulsory. Each module takes approximately 15 minutes.

Lectures

Weekly interactive lectures are provided on Monday afternoons 16:00 - 17:50. A detailed schedule of lectures will be provided on Learn.UQ. Lectures will be recorded and made available on Learn.UQ, however in-person attendance is recommended to benefit from the interactive elements, and fully engage with the new content fully prior to the Tuesday morning tutorials.

In week 7 there is no lecture as the in-semester exam is scheduled 15:00 - 17:30.

In week 10 there is no live lecture due to the Monday public holiday. Students will have access to a pre-recorded lecture to watch in their own time this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

Tutorials are in-person, last 1.5 hours and will not be recorded.

These sessions are designed as experiential learning activities, and participants are expected to attend and actively engage. Students will reflect upon the learning activities individually and with peers. This is a time for practice and refinement of specific skills in small groups.

A detailed schedule of tutorial topics will be provided on Learn.UQ.

During the final 10 minutes of 11 of the 13 tutorials, students will be guided to compile a brief written reflection on an element of the tutorial. These reflections form the ‘Tutorial Reflections’ described in the Assessment section of the ECP, and more detail is provided in the assessment task description on Learn.UQ.

The week 11 tutorial provides a particular practical experience, preparing students for the final interview assessment in the end of semester exam period. In this tutorial students will also provide a peer with feedback on their interview skills. Each student needs to give and receive peer feedback as this forms the basis of the Reflection Report assessment.

The week 13 tutorial will provide support in preparing for the final two pieces of assessment (Reflection Report and Final Interview).


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06
